item.title: Ticket #169 (get_links_list() in wp-includes/links.php ignores $text_after_link settings) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: get_links_list() is purposely hard-coded to use list items. That's why it is get_links_*list*. You can use wp_get_links() if you want to use the DB defaults. That method can be modified to allow listing all link categories rather than just one. Or, we can deprecate all of the link settings junk and clear that cruft out of the links UI.

item.title: Changeset [1924]: Rationalize menu access levels. Submenus should have an access level ...
item.dc:creator: rboren
item.description: Rationalize menu access levels. Submenus should have an access level greater than or equal to its parent. Require level 8 for all file editing pages.

item.title: Ticket #490 (Escape character before quotes and parenthesis) updated
item.dc:creator: dziner
item.description:
AUTHOR: Jonathan TITLE: Bye Bye Netflix STATUS: Publish ALLOW COMMENTS: 1 CONVERT BREAKS: default ALLOW PINGS: 1 PRIMARY CATEGORY: Personal CATEGORY: Personal

DATE: 12/06/2004 08:12:28 AM

BODY: I cancelled my Netflix subscription this morning. I'm finding it difficult to find time to sit down and watch the movies I rent. After cancelling my subscription I was taken to a quick survey. One of the questions hinted to a new feature possibility where you could put your account on hold for $.99. If I could do that, I wouldn't cancel my account. But sometimes I get too busy to be able to sit down and watch enough movies to make it worth my money.

EXTENDED BODY:

EXCERPT:

KEYWORDS:

COMMENT: AUTHOR: Scotbuff EMAIL: scotbuff@… IP: 12.177.52.245 URL: ​http://www.nitevilla.net DATE: 12/06/2004 10:24:03 AM I had canceled my Netflix subscription when they raised the price last winter. Because like you I was not watching a lot of movies and I could not justify the cost of continuing at a higher price. Netflix has since then dropped it's price to an amount lower than I was originally paying. I have been considering signing up again. Especially if they had the option of placing your account on hold.

COMMENT: AUTHOR: shane EMAIL: shane@… IP: 64.235.166.37 URL: ​http://shane.5twenty8.com DATE: 12/06/2004 07:23:29 PM It will be interesting to see how they do as on demand cable/satellite continues to expand.

item.title: Ticket #353 (Wordpress thinks the index page is a 404 page) updated
item.dc:creator: kopa
item.description: To add some information: I'm hosting with dreamhost.com which per default is running php as a cgi - which seems to be the root of the cause. If I change to running php as a module the problem is gone. But securitywise dreamhost advises to stay on php as cgi. Hope that there is a solution for those of us who can't/won't run php as an apache module.

item.title: Ticket #494 (PHP in Static Pages) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
The problem with using Theme templates to create such pages is that it then becomes theme-specific. If WordPress and other PHP functions were allowed to be inserted into pages easily, you could make an archives page that would be Theme-independent (the page would still display properly if you switch themes).

2fargon, I think you know full well that "static" pages aren't termed as such because they're forbidden from having any dynamic properties. ;)

The fact is this sort of functionality is commonly desired. WP should support it out of the box. (A simple checkbox perhaps?)

item.title: Ticket #490 (Escape character before quotes and parenthesis) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Here is an example of the text file from MT:

I never thought I would come across such strict resistance to the term "blog". I've had ideas for ways we can impliment a blog-esque system at work for a long time now. There's numerous reasons why you would want the end-user to have a more one-on-one feel with your website. It would be great to see fresh content on a regular basis controlled by numerous people.

Meanwhile, our competitors are building sites with new and improved features and we are slowly falling behind. What a better freaking time to impliment so cool freakin' features! Oh wait, we can't use a "blog" on our site because blogs are for younger people. Well, that's what the bigwigs say. Little do they know that it is simply a way to update fresh content on a site.

I've told them time and time again that comments can be moderated or turned off for security reasons. We obviously wouldn't want people posting rude things on our site. One of the reasons I have moderated comments on here because of my ex-girlfriend (many of you may have read some of the rude comments she posted here before this was implimented).

They came up with an idea to post "tech tip articles" which would be provided to me via Word document, then I would manually build a page, archives, etc. Ummm... isn't that what a BLOG is for? Ugghh... some people just don't get it!

Sorry, but I'm pissed about this situation and needed to vent.

NOTE: The escape characters actually show up on the admin pages as well. So I'm thinking that it has nothing to do with the MT export file at all.

item.title: Ticket #232 (Need a comment_type()-like function that returns comment type instead ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Korgan
item.description:
Actually, instead of creating a new function for this purpose, why not continue to use the existing comment_type() but with a preloaded var that determines behaviour?

Just add to the definition a simple $echo=true var.

So...

function comment_type($commenttxt = 'Comment', $trackbacktxt = 'Trackback', $pingbacktxt = 'Pingback', $echo = true) { }

Then at the end of the comment just have a conditional check. If $echo is false, return the value. If true, echo the value.

I am working on putting a lot of this sort of functionality into as many functions as I can then will submit the patches and updates to Ryan. It won't be quick, but I am hoping to get it into 1.3 as soon as I can.

item.title: Ticket #527 (<title> element in post is not parsed correctly) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #527 (<title> element in post is not parsed correctly) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
If you put '<title>' somewhere in your post, Wordpress will not escape the '<' and '>' and a HTML title element is inserted in the post. This results in a post that stops where the title element is inserted (at least in Firefox).

The correct behaviour would be that '<' and '>' would be parsed into '>' etc.

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #526 (Post Excerpts should be filtered) created
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description:
Currently, post excerpts go through a process to strip out images and HTML, which is a good thing--unless you're using Markdown, Textile, or some other post filter (in which case the syntax of the markup language are included in the excerpts).

To fix this, Wordpress should apply any enabled filters before stripping the HTML for post exceprts.
